Clients.AllowClaims: Allow client claims to be sent for all grant types
Clients.PrefixClaims: Choose the text you would like to prefix claims with
Clients.Restrictions: Identity providers the client application can use. If empty, all providers are allowed. Reference by AuthorityScheme within IdentityServer.

RequireConsent.Title: Require Consent?
RequireConsent.Help: Specifies whether a consent screen is required

AllowRememberConsent.Title: Remember Consent?
AllowRememberConsent.Help: Specifies whether consent screen is remembered after having been given

RequireSecret.Title: Require Secret?
RequireSecret.Help: Specifies whether a secret is required

Tokens.Title: Tokens
Tokens.UserSSOLifetimeTooltip: Amount of time between user authentication challenges. Defaults to the IdentityServer session lifetime
Tokens.UpdateAccessTokensSummary: Update access tokens (and its claims) when refresh token is used.
Tokens.UpdateAccessTokens: Update Access Token Claims On Refresh
Tokens.AccessTokensViaBrowser: Allow access tokens to be sent via browser
Tokens.AccessTokensViaBrowserSummary: Disabling is useful for hardening flows that allow for multiple grant types.
Tokens.IncludeUserClaimsInIdToken: Always Include User Claims In Id Token

Home.Title: Setup a Client Application
Home.Description:
Choose an application type from the list to find out more.
Then click "Start" to begin setup.

MachineToMachine.Title: Machine
MachineToMachine.Description:
A machine-to-machine method of communication.
No users are involved in the process.
Tokens will be sent via back-channel communication.

SPA.Title: Single Page App
SPA.Description:
A client-side application running in a browser.
These applications cannot be trusted to keep secrets or use refresh tokens.
Tokens will be sent through via the browser and will be visible to the user.

LegacySPA.Setup: Setup a Legacy Single Page Application
LegacySPA.Title: Single Page App (legacy)
LegacySPA.Description:
A client-side application running in a browser using previous OAuth Working Group recommendations.
These applications cannot be trusted to keep secrets or use refresh tokens.
Tokens will be sent through via the browser and will be visible to the user.

WebApp.Title: Web App
WebApp.Description:
A server-side application running on your infrastructure.
These applications can be trusted to keep a secret and use refresh tokens.
Tokens will be sent to a back-end server and will not be visible to the user.

NativeApp.Title: Native
NativeApp.Description:
A desktop or mobile application running on a user's device.
These applications cannot be trusted to keep a secret but can use refresh tokens.
Token visibility dependent on browser and redirect URI choice.

DeviceFlow.Title: Device
DeviceFlow.Description:
An IoT application or otherwise browserless or input constrained device.
These applications typically cannot be trusted to keep a secret but can use refresh tokens.

Saml.Title: SAML Service Provider
Saml.Description:
A SAML 2.0 service provider commonly used by government and educational institutions.
Cannot be used for API access.
Saml.LocationBindingUnique: Endpoint and binding type must be unique
Saml.RequireRequestDestinationHelp: Ensures that incoming SAML requests include a destination value, allowing IdentityServer to confirm that it is the intended recipient (recommended)
Saml.SignAssertionsHelp: Makes IdentityServer sign both SAML messages and assertions (recommended)
Saml.EncryptAssertionsHelp: Makes IdentityServer encrypt assertions sent to the Service Provider, using their public key
Saml.AddCertSummary: Upload a certificate or paste the certificate value from meta data
Saml.AddCertNote: The certificate will be applied immediately upon saving
Saml.ServiceProviderSigningCertHelp: X509Certificate value of the Service Provider's public key
Saml.DuplicateCertMessage: This certificate already exists on this service provider
Saml.CannotDeleteResponseCert: Cannot delete encryption certificate while encrypt assertions is true

WsFed.Title: WS-Fed Relying Party
WsFed.Description:
A WS-Federation relying party commonly used by older Microsoft applications.
Cannot be used for API access.

URLS.Title: Application URLs
URLS.SendTokens: Can send tokens to this URL
URLS.RedirectAfterLogout: Can redirect to this URL after logout
URLS.CORSDomain: Domain that can make cross-origin requests
URLS.URLAddUnsuccessful: There was a problem adding your URL

Clients.SloEndpointHelp: SLO endpoint URL. These protocols rely upon TLS in production
